title: 105_hr2985
content: Aliens are ineligible for visas and excluded from admission for nonpayment of child support. Aliens can be deemed inadmissible for visas and entry if they fail to pay child support exceeding $5,000, as per an amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act. This amendment applies to visas issued 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act has been amended to make aliens deportable for nonpayment of child support exceeding $5,000. Additionally, aliens can be ineligible for naturalization if they fail to pay child support. Aliens may be ineligible for naturalization if they fail to pay child support as legally obligated. The amendment applies to naturalization applications filed 180 days after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, certain arriving aliens can be served legal process in child support cases. Immigration officers can serve legal process on alien applicants for admission to enforce child support obligations, as defined by the Social Security Act. This authority is granted under an amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act. The term 'legal process' refers to any writ, order, summons, or similar process issued by a court or administrative agency in the United States. The amendment applies to aliens seeking admission to the US 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows the Immigration and Naturalization Service to request information on delinquent child support payments from the Secretary.
